channel.title: Movement to Music
channel.description: Recent content on Movement to Music

item.title: Leon Theremin
item.description: Image source: YouTube Instrument: Theremin (1920s) Leon Theremin created an instrument in the 1920s named after him: the Theremin. The Theremin is an electronic instrument where you don’t touch it at all!

item.title: Michel Waisvisz
item.description: Image source: STEIM.org VHS archive Instrument: The Hands (1970s) Michel Waisvisz, a Dutch composer and inventor, developed a groundbreaking instrument called The Hands. This instrument allowed him to control electronic sounds by simply moving his hands in the air.

item.title: Laurie Spiegel
item.description: Image source: YouTube, @jonmerel Instrument: Music Mouse (1980s) Laurie Spiegel created a special computer program called Music Mouse that let people make music by moving their computer mouse. With this program, she could control melodies and harmonies by just moving the mouse around the screen, letting her compose music in a new way.

item.title: Laetitia Sonami
item.description: Image source: Cartier Foundation for Contemporary Art Instrument: Lady’s Glove (1990s) Laetitia Sonami’s special glove had sensors that let her make music by moving her hands. She could control different sounds or even lights by bending her fingers or waving her arm.

item.title: Pamela Z
item.description: Image source: YouTube @PamelaZ Instrument: BodySynth (1990s) Pamela Z uses sensors placed on her body like jewelry to create music. When she moves her hands or body, the sensors send signals to a computer, which changes the sounds she is making in real time during her performances.

item.title: Imogen Heap
item.description: Image source: Dezeen Instrument: Mi.Mu Gloves (2000s) Imogen Heap’s gloves let her control the music she’s playing in concerts without touching anything. She can make sounds louder, softer, or change their pitch just by moving her hands and fingers in certain ways.

item.title: Atau Tanaka
item.description: Image source: YouTube @atautana Instrument: Muscle Sensors (2000s) Atau Tanaka uses special sensors that track the movements of his muscles. As he moves his arms or tightens his muscles, the sensors send information to a computer that turns those movements into sound.

item.title: Bjork
item.description: Image source: YouTube, Reactable Legacy Instrument: Reactable, Biophilia app (2000s) Bjork (said like bee-york) used a device called the Reactable, where she placed blocks on a table to control different sounds by moving them around.

item.title: Marco Donnarumma
item.description: Image source: YouTube Instrument: XTH Sense (2000s) Marco Donnarumma is known for using XTH Sense, a biosensor technology he developed that captures the sound of muscle movements in real time. By attaching the sensors to his body, Donnarumma can control electronic sounds through his muscle contractions and body movements, making his body both the performer and the instrument.
